comments.commentBody:
Great puzzle! I thought I would never get anything and then the pieces started to mesh. I had to regroup after putting the the appropriate (but wrong) DARTH and IONIC.

The final box got filled in when I suddenly got a mental picture of a bottle of Dos Equis.

Adam Smith rightly saw the dangers of this more than 200 years ago:

"The proposal of any new law or regulation which comes from [businessmen], ought always to be listened to with great precaution, and ought never to be adopted till after having been long and carefully examined, not only with the most scrupulous, but with the most suspicious attention. It comes from an order of men, whose interest is never exactly the same with that of the public, who have generally an interest to deceive and even to oppress the public, and who accordingly have, upon many occasions, both deceived and oppressed it."

–Adam Smith, An Inquiry into the Nature and Cause of the Wealth of Nations, vol. 1, pt. xi, p.10 (at the conclusion of the chapter)(1776)

If we could just wall this "Awful Evilness" of Republican spirit and the lies that propel it in the states of the Old Confederacy, it might be survivable. Republican state legislative gerrymandering is going to make it difficult for the Democrats to recapture Congress, and the money and will to expose the Republican Lies is just not there.
Until the Democratic Party figures out how to use this kind of truth to their advantage and turn out the vote, the fracturing of our nation in favor of the Plutocrats will centime.

Sad.

Come on.

This lawsuit reminds me of the lawsuit brought by The Marlboro Man when he got lung cancer.
Hockey is a violent sport at all levels.  This lawsuit is needless.  These players knew what is was all about before they joined the NHL.

Had a problem right from the get-go at 1A, as I felt "Fall Back" is far more commanding than MOVEBACK when ordering a 'Retreat!'
I liked the crossing of FATCATS and KITTENS and figured our FRIXWDP constructor, Peter Wentz, must've been really Feline it around this time?
Got completely faked out of my Hush Puppies @ 23D as I was convinced it was "Honcho" instead of POOBAH!

"TOOTOO Tootsie, Goodbye!"

WHH
I'm having trouble parsing that, but I think you're mintsing words again.

Please Excuse moi, for having hiccuped!?

Howie TBOQ

Had a problem right from the get-go at 1A, as I felt "Fall Back" is far more commanding than MOVEBACK when ordering a 'Retreat!'
I liked the crossing of FATCATS and KITTENS and figured our FRIXWDP constructor, Peter Wentz, must've been really Feline it around this time?
Got completely faked out of my Hush Puppies @ 23D as I was convinced it was "Honcho" instead of POOBAH!

"TOOTOO Tootsie, Goodbye!"

WHH

As a man who played the game from age six until age 52 in organized leagues, It is a total surprise to me that the NHL was able to keep secret the fact the getting punched in the face by big, strong guys who practice fighting on skates could cause head injuries.

Who knew?

Amen!  I have been a rec league player for 20 years and lament that I cannot take my children to see NHL games because of the explicit message that fighting is an acceptable way to resolve disputes - in sport and by extension in life.  The NHL is getting what it deserves - well, maybe - with these lawsuits.  Whatever good Bettman has done for the game in his 20 years as Commissioner, is diminished greatly by his failure to take on this problem.  Don Cherry, a guy who is hard not to like if you are a hockey fan, is also part of the problem, supporting the "old school" hockey culture and emphatically behind fighting.

He who Live by the sword, so he shall die by the sword. Can't blame the blacksmith.

Also of note these guys would have been truck drivers if not for their tough-guy qualities - Peluso was no rod Gilbert. They knew, or should have known the risks, they accepted them implicitly when they signed I the dotted line.
What's the old joke?  I went to a prize fight and a hockey game broke out.

"Hockey is a rough game, players are skating at high speeds, they have sticks, sharp skates and are making hard body contact with one another. There are bound to be fights" "I don't like to fight but I will not shy away".
Former NY Ranger great Rod Gilbert, who is basically saying the implements of the sport create an environment where fights can abrupt due to the hard physical contact that is part of play. I can understand how it happens having played the sport for many years. As Rod said, hockey is a rough game.

One thing that is wrong with "being loyal to one's fellow Americans" is that this loyalty often results in distrust, dislike, exclusion of others and cruel behavior.  Wouldn't it be much better to be loyal to all humanity?

Evidently the fans enjoy the fights. Maybe if less alcohol was sold at hockey games the fans would be able to notice and enjoy the players' skill. I remember the days when there were steep and increasing fines for fighting. If you came off the bench to join in you were fined even more. I don't remember any of the old time players having serious injuries from the game and this was before face guards.
Yes, the game is dangerous but the league has allowed it to get out of hand. What used to be a quick few punches and off to the penalty box has become deliberate injury to another player or prolonged fights with the idea of doing damage. The teams have hired players to do the job and everyone knows it. The penalty should be that the perpetrator can't come back to play until the injured party can. It's time to return skill instead of brute force back to the game. It may take a lawsuit to do it.

Hockey is an odd sport when it comes to ritualized violence. You can't hit the guy who wears the most padding - the goalie - but if you do, even inadvertently, everyone on his team goes nuts and wants to beat the snot out of you. Think what the ritual requires: drop your gloves and punch someone in order to protect the guy who wears more padding than you do. Fighting and the incessant post-whistle, little-boy pushing and shoving ruins the game - has always ruined the game. Now, it's abundantly clear it has - ruined the lives of some protagonists. For what?

This has to be a joke. Everyone knows the NHL loves the fighting and the fans expect it. You don't see tough penalties. Ever seen a player fined $50,000 for fighting? Never. You see the refs standing around watching the fights. And for the "brawlers" who were expected to fight to be suing the league is laughable. They loved their titles and willingly started fights for the fans. The NHL is one step above professional wrestling when it comes to the fights.

Whether from the juniors or college, you know that in the NHL fighting is part of the game. Why? Because it's a game of intimidation, where you can jab an opponent in the ribs with the butt of a stick and never be seen by a ref. At some point, unless you enjoy bruised ribs, you need to let the jerk know that's enough, it's time to drop the gloves. Eliminate fighting and you sign on to dirty tactics run rampant.

For anyone who suggests that every team has a goon, those days disappeared in the early 80's. Few teams can give up a roster spot to a guy whose primary job is to take out the best opposing player.
Fighting may be wrong, but claiming the league did not "warn" them is ridiculous. They were not forced to become hockey players. Did they grow up in a vacuum having never seen a professional game?
Never thought I would care who won a hockey match, but today I am rooting for the players.

It's about time to corral fighting.......I've enjoyed the game at all levels since the 1960s, playing at various amateur and intramural collegiate levels, and as a seasons ticket holder with my local NHL club. I believe there is no reason for such fisticuffs. Think it adds anything to the game? Then watch a Division I college or an Olympic game, and think about it again. Was the US/Canada game in the recent Olympics not good enough? (Except for the outcome, of course....).

Fighting both is dangerous to the players and breaks the flow of an up-tempo game.

"the complaint said that the N.H.L. failed to take adequate steps to warn the players of the dangers of the sport"

If you believe that I know of a bridge in Brooklyn you might want to buy, or maybe some cigarettes that are good for your health.

Having said that, it is quite clear that in years past various leagues sold the violence aspect. It could hardly be a mystery to players that the danger was not an illusion. The term "punch drunk" did not come from no-where.
I guess you would like the fights in the Roman Coliseum as well.  Some of us enjoy hockey.  Too bad the Olympics only comes around every 4 years.
You are the NHL's primary market, you being the kind of person that enjoys watching people get their brains bashed but with a corporate veneer.  You were born about 2000 years too late.

Head injuries,concussions,depression and permanent brain damage are”part of the game?” and you believe limiting life threatening violence will “sterilize it”.
How sad.

It's not part of the game! Contact, hard hits, OK-but to allow them to stand there and punch each other .....Imagine if every sport tolerated that-if that is what you watch it for, or think it "part of the game" you need to switch sports-watch boxing, it is the game.

It's part of the game but, alas we will sterilize it like everything else.  I hate the direction the world is headed because we are pretending human nature has changed along with the liberal societal mores being forced upon us.  It will come back to bite us in the distant future.  I've been a Ranger's fan for 35 years.....here's to the upcoming playoffs!

If promoting fighting (Rule Breaking) is due to insufficient fine amounts or sanctioning.

What does that say about our justice system and repeat offenders?

Please Excuse moi, for having hiccuped!?

Howie TBOQ
